body.p: Вы можете ответствовать святителю, что менее всего ожидать надлежало благотворительной руке от святительской особы, осыпанной, отличенной и возведенной щедростию и щедротами, безразсудный толк известной переписки, которой одно злобой наполненное сердце лишь может дать кривое толкование; понеже сама собою та переписка весьма невинна, и в такое время, когда тот осьмидесяти-летний старик старался своими, во всей Европе жадно читаемыми, сочинениями прославить Россию, унизить врагов ея и удержать деятельную вражду своих соотчичей, кои тогда старались распространить повсюду язвительную злобу противу дел нашего Отечества, в чем и предуспел. В таком виду и намерении письма, писанныя к безбожнику, кажется, не нанесли вреда ни церкви, ни Отечеству.This letter was written in response to a denunciation sent from Moscow by Archpriest Petr Alekseev to Khrapovitsky on 3 September 1789. Alekseev claimed that Platon, Metropolitan of Moscow, was showing people Voltaire's correspondence with Catherine, which risked casting doubt on Catherine's Orthodoxy because she corresponded with an 'atheist'. Alekseev alleged Platon might even have it translated into Russian, which would be dangerous because more 'Русские безразсудные читатели' ('thoughtless Russian readers') would come to such conclusions. K.A. Papmehl reads Catherine's response as showing that the denunciation 'stirred her ire against Platon to an unprecedented degree', citing as evidence Alekseev's next letter to Khrapovitsky, in which he promised '"to carry out the tasks I am entrusted with in a suitable manner, using the Prelate's favourites who are also my friends"'. Papmehl adds that in the letter to commander-in-chief of Moscow, Eropkin, sent a week later, 'Catherine thus baited a trap for Platon', in asking none other than the Metropolitan himself to censor the complete works of Voltaire, published by Beaumarchais (Metropolitan Platon of Moscow, pp. 51-52). It is true also that Alekseev continued to provide denunciations, especially against Freemasons, in coming years. One might venture, however, a different reading of the present episode. If already in 1789 Catherine already detested the Metropolitan as much as is claimed, it would seem strange that in the coming years Platon continued to correspond with Grigory Potemkin, while the new commander-in-chief of Moscow, A.A. Prozorovsky, trusted him to appoint censors for Nikolay Novikov's archive. Moreover, when, in 1792, Catherine finally yielded to Platon's repeated requests to retire, she kept him in his official post, while giving his duties to a subordinate. Platon may have complained, but one can only imagine that Catherine kept him on for so long because she still found Platon useful and effective. If she had really been angry with him, she could surely have removed him earlier and/or less honorably. (See Papmehl, Metropolitan Platon, pp. 54-55.) In this particular case of Voltaire's correspondence, Catherine must have known that Platon would be condemning himself by casting doubt on her Orthodoxy via the letters to Voltaire: after all, Platon himself received enthusiastic support from Voltaire, who praised his sermon on the victory at Chesme as worthy of the philosopher Plato. Accordingly, it is tempting to suggest that Catherine might have even perceived the twisted heart of Alekseev and guessed that he was the one responsible for the misguided interpretation of the Voltaire letters. Alekseev, a noted denunciator and man of continual bad faith, wanted to puff himself up by claiming that Khrapovitsky's relation of the contents of Catherine's note was in fact a special mission against Platon. (For further related materials, see 'Iz bumag Protoiereya Petra Alekseeva', pp. 73-76; 'Petr Alekseev, protopop Moskovskogo Arkhangel'skogo sobora (1727-1801)'.

You can answer the holy man that there was no one from whom a munificent hand could have less expected a rash interpretation of the said correspondence than from a holy individual, who has been showered with and distinguished and elevated by generosity and bounties. Only a heart filled with malice could take it amiss. For, the correspondence was in itself most innocent and took place at a time when that eighty-year-old man was trying, in writings that were avidly read all over Europe, to glorify Russia, to abase her enemies, and to restrain the active enmity of his compatriots, who were then attempting to spread biting malice against the affairs of our Fatherland. In this he succeeded. Letters written to an atheist with this intent and purpose, it would seem, caused no harm either to the Church or to the Fatherland.
